result.execSummary:
The defendant Michelle L. Powers was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Michelle L. Powers is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Michelle L. Powers was found guilty of OWI (7th, 8th or 9th), a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Cases called: 10CF211& 10CF145 (both are sentencing after revocation) & 15CF396, Defendant Michelle L. Powers in court, in custody with attorney Steven James Sarbacker. Troy Cross appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Rights/elements gone over. Defendant plead no contest to count one in the Information.  Repeater dismissed in cts. 1&2. Statements by defendant's mom, friend of the family and defendant. Court sentenced defendant to 5 yrs. prison; consisting of 3 years confinement and 2 years Extended Supervision, consecutive to 10CF211 & 10CF145. 36 mo. revocation, 36 mo. IID. Submit DNA sample. Complete AODA, follow all treatment recommendations. $518 costs. Ct. 2 dismissed. Jail credit 232 In 10CF211, Court sentenced defendant on both counts to 4 yrs. prison; consisting of 2 years confinement and 2 years Extended Supervision, concurrent with each other, consecutive to 10CF145, Jail credit 205 unpaid costs condition of Extended Supervision. In 10CF145, Court sentenced defendant to 4 yrs. prison; consisting of 2 years confinement and 2 years Extended Supervision, Jail credit 210 unpaid costs condition of Extended Supervision. On all three cases, Defendant is not eligible for Substance Abuse Program, but is eligible for the Early Release Program.
